Morrisons’ shares up 6%; Ocado’s down 8%. It’s hard to argue with the market’s snap judgment on Monday’s strategic shuffles in the online grocery market.

On the principle that it’s better to be cuddly with the Amazonian monster than to stand in its path, the chief executive of Morrisons, David Potts, is being pragmatic in signing a deal to supply hundreds of fresh, frozen and ambient products to the US online retailer.

Morrisons is also the one major supermarket chain that produces a lot of its own food, by owning farms and manufacturing facilities. Arguably, that alters the economics of a tie-up with Amazon. Morrisons can still hope to make a profit as a manufacturer and wholesaler on its Amazon lines, even if it is surrendering the retailer’s profit margin. What’s more, Potts also breaks Morrisons’ previous reliance on Ocado’s services in the online market. He now has two partners.

Related: Amazon to start selling fresh and frozen Morrisons food

Trying to sound cheerful about this development, Ocado’s chief executive, Tim Steiner, describes his own potential extended distribution deal with Morrisons as a “win-win arrangement”. Perhaps it will be but it hasn’t been signed yet and Morrisons says it will proceed only if it brings “profitable online growth”. That may be code for Potts demanding better terms than his predecessor signed in the original Morrisons-Ocado partnership.

If it happens, the latest deal will differ from the first in two important ways. First, Morrisons won’t be putting up capital to buy half the Erith warehouse in south-east London, as it did at Dordon in Warwickshire. Second, for Morrisons deliveries in Scotland, Cornwall and parts of the north of England, a “store pick” model will be used, which runs counter to Ocado’s philosophy that centralised distribution is always best.

Maybe such compromises are just the price of getting things done, but it’s yet another thing for Ocado’s shareholders to worry about. They were promised a deal with an international retailer by the end of last year. That hasn’t happened yet, and instead there’s a different type of deal with an established customer that is cosying up to Amazon. Suddenly, the landscape looks complicated in Ocado-land. Waitrose seems to be an unreliable boyfriend for the long-term; now Morrisons is being cute with Amazon. As for the idea of Amazon buying Ocado, that now seems a non-starter.

For the rest of the supermarket sector, the question is whether Amazon is finally getting serious about groceries in the UK. The addition of “hundreds” – but not thousands – of Morrisons lines is an upgrade but not a game-changer. Amazon is still behaving like a souped-up convenience store, but the full-line offer is surely coming.

GSK chairman’s big decisions

Sir Philip Hampton, the new-ish chairman of GlaxoSmithKline, has two big items to deal with this year. One is to find a new chief executive since it is clear that Sir Andrew Witty, boss since 2008, is entering his last lap. The second is to respond to the persistent calls for GSK to be broken up. The best approach? Don’t confuse the two issues.

Advocates of a breakup are doing the opposite, naturally. Expect to hear a lot from the splitters about what Witty’s successor “must” do to address the underperformance of the share price over the past couple of years.

In reality, the argument for a breakup is wafer-thin – and probably still will be after Witty’s expected exit next year. The consumer products division is the obvious candidate for separation but the timing looks wrong. GSK and Novartis pooled their consumer assets only last year and set out ambitions to double the division’s profit margins by 2020. That plan needs time to work.

As for the vaccines operation, what would be the point of independence? It shares its sales and distribution network with the core pharmaceutical business and smooths out the bumps in earnings. Splitting off ViiV, the majority-owned HIV operation, is more plausible but when Witty toyed with the idea a couple of years ago shareholders told him not to sell.

Hampton should keep it simple: find the best person for the job, which is surely someone with more to offer than an overly simplistic breakup agenda.

RBS chief’s show of confidence

The chancellor can’t sell our Royal Bank of Scotland shares at the current shrivelled price, but management can buy a few. Its chief executive, Ross McEwan, and finance director, Ewen Stevenson, have bought £445,000-worth apiece. That’s a decent slug of stock.

Mind you, given what the duo earned in a lousy year for the bank, it would be rude – and a little worrying – if they didn’t show confidence in RBS at just 0.7 times book value.
